subject: Re: New file uploaded to Read_Alphabet
msgSnippet: ... Hi Oliver, I wrote the QsConverter program in Microsoft Visual C++ 6.0.  The user interface is based on Windows dialog boxes and their embedded controls
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, oliver langan
<oliverlangan@y...> wrote:
> > File : /QsConverter/QsConverter_1_1.zip
> > Uploaded by : jeff_smith_8992 <jeff_smith_8992@y...>
> > Description : This program allows the User to convert regular text
> > into QuikScript. Version 1.1 corrects the problems with hyphenated
> > words and adds a progress bar.
>
> Hi Jeff,
>
> What language is this written in? I use a Mac, and can't use windows
> executables, but it might be possible to cross-compile it into a Mac
> executable, or at least a command-line tool which could also be run on
> linux.
>
> oliver

Hi Oliver,

I wrote the "QsConverter" program in Microsoft Visual C++ 6.0. The
user interface is based on Windows dialog boxes and their embedded
controls (buttons, edit windows, popup messages, etc.).

I did a quick search online to see if there are any "quick and dirty"
translation programs that will cross-compile a Microsoft Visual C++
Windows program to a Unix X-Windows or to a Mac platform, but I didn't
find much. It looks (to me) like it would be a significant effort.

Since the basic concept behind "QsConverter" is very simple just take
a text input stream, parse it to isolate individual words, see if each
word is defined in Chuck Peck's dictionary, and then output the
resulting text in a QuikScript font), I think it would probably be
easier to write a new program from scratch than try to port my program.

Jeff
